summary: This document is a series of urgent emails from August 11-12, 2019, between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) regarding the immediate need to interview Bureau of Prisons staff following Jeffrey Epstein's death. The emails discuss interview logistics, legal procedures (Miranda warnings, subpoenas), and the legal authority to compel testimony.

persons.name: Donaleski, Rebekah
persons.context: Sends the primary email outlining the urgent need to interview Bureau of Prisons staff, specifying they must be Mirandized and given warnings. Coordinates the interview logistics.

persons.name: Roos, Nicolas
persons.context: Copied on the email chain, indicating involvement in the urgent investigation and coordination efforts.

persons.name: Amanda
persons.context: Mentioned as someone with whom the interview plan was discussed, indicating prior coordination on the investigation strategy.

connections.description: Both are Assistant U.S. Attorneys (USANYS) copied on the same urgent email chain coordinating the investigation into Epstein's death.
Donaleski references having discussed the interview plan with Amanda, indicating a working relationship in the investigation.

events.title: Planned Interviews of BOP Staff
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office urgently coordinates to interview at least 10 Bureau of Prisons staff members (duty officers and shift supervisors) regarding the circumstances of Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Urgent Coordination After Epstein's Death
events.description: Late-night email chain initiated to coordinate an immediate investigative response, indicating the event (Epstein's death) occurred very recently.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC New York) - Implied location as the facility where the BOP staff worked and where Epstein died.
keyFacts: The emails were sent on the night of August 11, 2019, immediately following Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody, indicating a rapid investigative response.

The U.S. Attorney's Office planned to interview at least 10 specific Bureau of Prisons staff members, including duty officers and shift supervisors from various shifts (e.g., 8/9 shift, 0:00-8:00 shift).

The interview plan included Mirandizing the staff, giving them 18 U.S.C. ยง 1001 warnings (against false statements), and having subpoenas ready to compel testimony if they invoked their right to counsel.

There was a legal discussion about whether the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) could compel testimony from BOP staff under a federal contract, versus the prosecutors' ability to use such compelled statements in a criminal case.
The document reveals intense, late-night coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) and the OIG to secure evidence and testimony immediately after a major incident in federal custody.
